thread.title: Bill Murray's biggest flops
thread.title_full: Bill Murray's biggest flops - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Bill Murray's biggest flops
text:
Al Pereira/Getty Images Bill Murray loves his Chicago Cubs, but they may not be his only loss this week with the release of critical dud "Rock the Kasbah." There are few celebrities more universally liked than Bill Murray, but the Cubs may not be the only thing he's disappointed with this week.
The comic icon and star of beloved films like "Scrooged," "Caddyshack" and "Rushmore" — along with his legendary knack for popping up in random places — has also starred in some complete flops.
Murray's new film, "Rock the Kasbah," which debuts on Friday, has so far drawn only 6% positive reviews from the critics, and looks poised to be a box office flop with "Steve Jobs" headed into wide release the same weekend.
Here are 10 of Murray's biggest flops, some with critics (via Rotten Tomatoes scores) and some with audiences.
"Larger than Life"
Who could've thought that the comedy team of Bill Murray and an elephant wouldn't pan out?
The comedy about a man who an inherits said elephant — co-starring Jeremy Piven, Janeane Garofalo and a young Matthew McConaughey — made just $8 million at the box office and was trashed by critics, garnering only 11% support on Rotten Tomatoes .
"The Lost City"
Hard for a film starring Bill Murray, Dustin Hoffman and Andy Garcia to be completely forgotten, but this one managed to do it, apparently.
The Garcia-directed production drew just $4 million at the box office and was disliked by 75% of critics .
"Space Jam"
A cult classic with a certain generation, but arguably still a mess of a buddy comedy starring Michael Jordan and Bugs Bunny.
Murray, a massive Chicago sports fan, plays himself in the combination live action-animation production.
It made over $200 million in box office gross worldwide, but scored only 35% on Rotten Tomatoes .
"Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties"
There's a popular story about this one: Murray only agreed to voice the lasagna-loving feline because he thought that the film's writer, Joel Coen, was one of the famous Coen brothers.
Cut to a few years later, and Murray is voicing the cat in a bleak live action-CGI sequel.
It was not as financially successful as the first film, and curried the favor of only 11% of critics .
"A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III"
This film was made just after the period of time where Charlie Sheen was screaming at us about winning and drinking so-called tiger blood.
Writer-director Roman Coppola — son of Francis Ford Coppola and frequent Wes Anderson collaborator — made this mess about a ladies man (Sheen) who's life, wait for it, goes into a tailspin after a breakup.
Trashed by critics , the film made a mere $210,000.
“Hyde Park on Hudson”
This one was a surprise, as it starred an Oscar nominated actor who portrayed an historical figure — typical bait for film award ceremonies.
Instead, people didn't quite seem to enjoy Murray playing FDR — with the film making a paltry $11 million and scoring just 36% positive reviews .
Murray, however, was nominated for a Golden Globe for the performance.
"The Monuments Men"
Claudette Barius "The Monuments Men" was successful financially, but a flop with critics. Another seemingly Oscar-bait picture that included a star-studded cast re-enacting a non-fiction book set in World War II.
George Clooney directed this film about a group that has to find and save culturally important art from the Nazis before its destroyed.
Despite a cast that included Clooney, Murray, Matt Damon, John Goodman and Cate Blanchett, "Monuments" only drew 31% positive reviews and no awards recognition, though it did make $150 million at the box office.
"Aloha"
This film seemingly falls into a category of projects that Murray chose either because they involved prior collaborators he liked or they included people who have done good work (unless it turns out to not be the Coen brother you think it is).
Cameron Crowe's "Aloha," which starred an ensemble cast including Bradley Cooper, Emma Stone, Alec Baldwin and other big stars, scored a paltry 19% on Rotten Tomatoes and couldn't recoup its $37 million budget.
"Passion Play"
A movie written and directed by Mitch Glazer, the same man who wrote and directed "Rock the Kasbah," flopped for Murray long before this current bomb.
Murray plays a ruthless gangster trying to harm an angel played by Megan Fox. Mickey Rourke starred as the trumpet player trying to save him.
This did not pan out with critics - who hated it ( 3% on Rotten Tomatoes! ) - and audiences, who didn't see it. The film made less than $3,000 at the box office.
"Hamlet"
This is not the 1996 Kenneth Brannagh-directed version of "Hamlet," but a modernized take on the Shakespeare tale, set in New York City.
The movie came out in 2000 and starred Ethan Hawke as Hamlet, with Murray playing the smaller role of Polonius.
While it drew a somewhat respectable 55% on Rotten Tomatoes , it bombed at the box office to the tune of $2 million in returns.
slepore@nydailynews.com
Tags: news break , lists , bill murray
